Dylan Field’s story on how Figma started →
The Gap They Found (2016):


Interviewed 100+ designers about workflow pain points
Universal complaint: “I email design files back and forth all day”
Insight: Design tools needed to work like Google Docs, not Photoshop



Research-Driven Decisions:


✅ Browser-based (controversial!) ✅ Real-time collaboration ✅ Free tier for network effects ✅ Comments directly on designs

❌ Native app (slower to build) ❌ Paid-only (limits growth) ❌ Traditional licensing




The Outcome: 0 → Industry standard in 6 years | $20B Adobe acquisition


Students use Figma—they get it
They didn’t build a better design tool, they researched the design PROCESS
Show how research challenges assumptions (browser vs native)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
When Designers Skip Research…


Juicero: The $120 Million Juice Mistake 🧃
Watch the infamous Bloomberg video → | Full story →


The Product:

$400 WiFi-connected juicer
Sleek design, beautiful branding
VC funding: $120 million

The Research They Skipped:

“Do people want this?”
“Is a $400 juicer solving a real problem?”
“Can users just… squeeze the packets by hand?”


The Reality:
Bloomberg tested it: Yes, you can squeeze the packets by hand. Same juice.
The Outcome:

Company shut down 16 months later
Became a Silicon Valley punchline






Show the Bloomberg video (30 seconds) - it’s hilarious
Students find this memorable—failure is entertaining
Lesson: Research isn’t just “make it pretty”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: More Fails You Can Learn From
text:
More Fails You Can Learn From


Theranos: Design Without Function →

Sleek design, great branding
Problem: Product didn’t work
Research fabrication → fraud → collapse
Lesson: Research ≠ making it look good


Zoom Fatigue (2020) →

Initial design: Great for 1-hour meetings
Didn’t anticipate: 8-hour Zoom days
Had to retrofit: Virtual backgrounds, touch-up appearance, “hide self-view”
Lesson: Test edge cases and extreme usage







The Pattern


All of these teams had designers. What they lacked was research.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: 🎮 Activity: Reverse Engineer Your Favorite Apps
text:
🎮 Activity: Reverse Engineer Your Favorite Apps
Pick ONE app you use daily. Discuss in pairs (3 minutes):


What problem does it solve?
What user need did they discover through research?
What’s ONE design decision that clearly came from user testing?






Examples to Consider


Notion (flexibility research) | BeReal (authenticity fatigue) | Duolingo (habit loop gamification) | Discord (community vs. chat)





Students share out after 3 minutes
Validate their observations
Show how research is everywhere once you look for it

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
⚡ Lightning Round: Spot the Research
What was researched to create these features?


Instagram’s Double-Tap to Like

Answer: Thumb reach zones, one-handed phone use

Spotify’s “Made For You” Playlists

Answer: Music discovery is stressful, users want curation

Dark Mode (iOS, Twitter, Apps)

Answer: Eye strain studies, battery life data, user preference surveys

TikTok’s Infinite Scroll (vs. “Are You Still Watching?”)

Answer: Deliberate friction reduces engagement (they researched both!)




Takeaway: Every pixel can be a research decision.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Bridging Academic & Practice 🌉
You might be thinking: “Why learn academic research methods when I want to design products?”


The Academic Toolkit

Systematic thinking: How to frame research questions
Methodology selection: Choosing the right approach
Analysis frameworks: Making sense of data
Critical evaluation: Assessing quality and bias
Clear communication: Writing and presenting findings


Applied in the Real World
When Airbnb flew to New York, they used ethnographic methods (academic)
When Figma interviewed 100 designers, they did qualitative research (academic)
When Spotify A/B tests Wrapped, they use experimental design (academic)
The difference? Speed and scope—not the underlying thinking.






💡 Bottom Line


Learn the rigorous academic approach, adapt it for the fast-paced product world. The thinking stays the same.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Three Main Approaches


🔍 Primary Research
You gather the data

Interviews
Observations
Surveys
Usability tests
Ethnography

Best for: Specific product questions

📚 Secondary Research
Others gathered the data

Market reports
Competitor analysis
Trend studies
Academic papers
User reviews

Best for: Understanding landscape

🔀 Mixed Methods
Combine both

Surveys + Interviews
Analytics + User testing
Quantitative + Qualitative

Best for: Complex problems




Week 2 will dive deeper into methodologies
Today: Just know they exist and serve different purposes

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Real Designers Use Research


Jake Knapp (Google Ventures)

Created the “Design Sprint” method
Research insight: Teams waste months debating
Solution: Compress research + design + testing into 5 days
Used by: Slack, Airbnb, LEGO, Uber

Learn it: “Sprint” by Jake Knapp

Julie Zhuo (Meta/Facebook)

Teen user research: “Parents on Facebook = uncool”
Led to: Separate features, stricter privacy controls
Design principle: “Design for the user you want, not the one you have”

Learn it: “The Making of a Manager” by Julie Zhuo




Show that research is a career skill, not just academic
These are people they could work with/for
Give them resources to learn more

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Reverse Engineer a Persona
Scenario: You’re redesigning Instagram for 2026

Step 1 (5 min): Pick a real person you know

How do they ACTUALLY use Instagram right now?
What do they complain about?
What keeps them scrolling?

Step 2 (5 min): Create a “Love/Hate” persona

3 things they hate about current Instagram
3 things they can’t live without
1 feature they wish existed

Step 3 (5 min): Share & find patterns

What’s common across personas?
What surprised you?
What would you need to research to validate these insights?




Use real people, not imaginary users
Focus on behaviors, not demographics
Look for patterns = research insights
What do we NOT know? = research gaps

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Debrief: What Did You Learn?
Discussion questions:


What assumptions did you have that turned out wrong?
What would you research first to validate your persona?
How would this change your design approach?






🎯 The Meta-Lesson


You just did primary research (interviewing someone) and synthesis (finding patterns). That’s the core research loop.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Can Research Kill Creativity?

“If I’d asked people what they wanted, they’d say faster horses.”
— Often attributed to Henry Ford




❌ The Myth
Ford ignored users and invented cars through genius alone

✅ The Reality
Ford DID extensive research:

Road conditions
Driver behavior
Manufacturing workflows
Competitor teardowns

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Research-Creativity Balance



Here’s The Truth



Research tells you the problems
Design solves them creatively
Research validates if you actually solved it





Research doesn’t kill creativity—it focuses it.


Bad research: “What color should this button be?”
Good research: “Why aren’t users completing checkout?”
Great research: “What’s the emotional journey of buying online?”




Address the common fear: “Research will make everything boring”
Research + creativity are partners, not enemies
Next week we’ll learn HOW to do good research

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Today’s Key Takeaways


💡 Research drives innovation by uncovering insights you’d never guess
💥 Skipping research is expensive (Juicero, Snapchat, Theranos)
🎯 Every successful product started with understanding users
🎨 Research ≠ boring—it makes design more creative and effective
⚡ You already do research—now you’ll learn to do it systematically

Two phases of literature review
Phase One: Catch-them-all

ID all relevant publications within your problem space
Read/Skim through more relevant ones and broaden your understanding

Phase Two: Write on Relevance

Synthesize your findings on the literature into writings
Present your own evaluation of the literature that you found relevant, both good and bad
Your background, reader’s roadmap of how your arguments are paved

2: What makes a story credible?
How do we transform raw facts into a compelling narrative?

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
section: 3: Let’s open with some ideas from Osman & Abramson
text:
3: Let’s open with some ideas from Osman & Abramson

Osman’s Idea:

Evidence is not self-explanatory.
Facts become “evidence” when selectively assembled into a narrative.

Abramson’s Contribution:

Advocates for an “undetermined history.”
Emphasizes embracing ambiguity, accident, and counter-narratives.


Leverage these ideas as the thread that stitches our session together.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
4: Session Overview & Objectives

Our Focus:

Use Osman & Abramson as theoretical anchors to examine research narratives.
Case study: “A Data-Driven Qualitative Review of Thermal Comfort Studies.”

Learning Outcomes:

Understand roles of primary vs. secondary data.
Recognize how narrative is constructed—and what is omitted.
Develop strategies for critical, reflexive evidence gathering.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
5: Introduction & Context Setting

Exploration:

How evidence and narrative work together in research.
Our case study is the provided draft on thermal comfort studies.

Focus:

Examining how the draft uses different data types to build its narrative.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
6: Dissecting the Draft’s Methodology

Data Collection:

Primary Data: Field measurements, surveys, direct observations.
Secondary Data: Established databases (e.g., ASHRAE, Chinese TCDB) and literature.

Systematic Approach:

Literature screening, numerical evaluation criteria (scores 0–3).
Mapping personal (age, gender, BMI) and contextual parameters.


This method exemplifies how facts are mobilized into evidence, as Osman suggests.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
section: 7: Mapping between perception and numbers: A Quantitative Review
text:
7: Mapping between perception and numbers: A Quantitative Review


What benefits and drawbacks do you see in using numerical scoring to convert raw data into a narrative?

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
8: Primary vs. Secondary Data Sources

Primary Data:

Direct measurements (e.g., temperature, humidity).
First-hand surveys and observations.

Secondary Data:

Data from previous studies and databases.
Provides context and broadens scope.


The draft combines both to create a layered narrative.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
section: 9: How Did We Do This in Our Manuscript?
text:
9: How Did We Do This in Our Manuscript?

Leveraging Secondary Data:

Utilized established thermal comfort databases (ASHRAE & Chinese TCDB) as our primary sources.
Compiled 88+ articles to form our evidence base.

Systematic Data Evaluation:

Applied a numerical scoring system (0–3) to assess personal, contextual, and PMV parameters.
Enabled structured comparison and identification of gaps across studies.

Constructing the Narrative:

Integrated diverse data points to build a coherent story that supports our hypothesis.
Demonstrated how selection and framing of secondary data can drive new insights.

Testament to Methodology:

Our approach shows that robust secondary data can be effectively leveraged.
Aligns with Osman’s and Abramson’s ideas on how evidence is reinterpreted into a narrative.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
10: Critically Assessing Our Data Setup

Maintain Critical Awareness:

Triangulation: Validate findings by comparing multiple sources.
Reflexivity: Regularly question data selection and categorization.
Iterative Review: Continuously refine data collection and narrative as new evidence emerges.

Draft’s Limitations:

Inconsistent classifications and mapping issues.
Underrepresentation of certain demographics.

Future Enhancements:

Develop standardized classification/predictive frameworks.
Incorporate mixed-method approaches.


This process embodies the critical reflection championed by Osman and Abramson.

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
section: 11: How can we ensure our data-driven narratives remain robust and adaptable as new evidence emerges?
text: 11: How can we ensure our data-driven narratives remain robust and adaptable as new evidence emerges?

title: Evidence and Narrative in Research: From Osman & Abramson to Thermal Comfort Studies
text:
12: Conclusion & Key Takeaways

Summary:

Evidence transforms into narrative through careful selection and interpretation.
Our case study demonstrates both the potential and limitations in this process.

Key Takeaways:

Balance rigorous data collection with reflexive narrative construction.
Be aware of what is included—and omitted—to strengthen research credibility.
Osman and Abramson remind us to remain open to alternative interpretations.


Final Reflection:
“As researchers, how do we balance the rigor of data collection with the interpretive nature of narrative construction?”

title: Literature Review Extended by Advanced Methods
section: Refresher on Introduction to Literature Review
text:
Refresher on Introduction to Literature Review
Purpose and Objectives

Definition: A comprehensive survey of publications relevant to a research topic.
Purpose: Establishes context, identifies gaps, and justifies new research.

Key Objectives

Synthesize existing knowledge.
Identify research gaps and questions.
Inform methodology.
Ground research in existing literature.

title: Literature Review Extended by Advanced Methods
text:
Types of Literature Reviews
Narrative Review

Broad, subjective overview.
Thematic analysis of literature.

Systematic Review

Structured, transparent approach.
Answers specific research questions.

Meta-Analysis

Combines data from multiple studies.
Statistical analysis to find effect size.

Scoping Review

Maps key concepts, types of evidence.
Informative for research areas.


Think of literature reviews like recipes for making a cake.

Narrative Review: A creative recipe with no specific ingredients or quantities. It’s like following your grandma’s “secret” recipe that works well but is hard to replicate.

Example: A general overview of the field, summarizing key points without quantitative data.

Thematic Analysis: A systematic approach to categorize and understand different flavors (themes) in a cake.

Example: Analyzing literature on a specific topic, identifying patterns or themes that emerge from the studies.

Systematic Review: A structured recipe book with detailed instructions, using established methods to find all relevant ingredients.

Example: Following a well-defined protocol to gather and synthesize all existing research on a particular question or intervention.

Meta-Analysis: A statistical analysis of multiple cake recipes to identify the “best” combination of ingredients.

Example: Quantitatively combining data from multiple studies to estimate the overall effect size or outcome.

Scoping Review: A rough sketch of different types of cakes and their ingredients, helping you understand what’s out there.

Example: Gathering information on a broad topic, identifying key concepts, and understanding the types of evidence available.

section: Primary Data Collection Methods: Desining Questionnaires
text:
Primary Data Collection Methods: Desining Questionnaires

a set of questions and secure answers from respondants
often analyzed by statsitical methods
consistency in questionnaires make cross-sectional analysis easy

Types of questions designed to measure variables in survey:

Close-end questions

Two-option aka dichotomous scales
More than two options: Nominal-polychromous
Ordinal-Polytomous scale
Continous or bounded types

Open-end questions

setence completion
open-ended questions with free text responses

title: Data, Data, Data, Collection Methodologies and Quantitative vs. Qualitative
section: Polytomous Variables, aka Options for Multiple Choice Questions
text:
Polytomous Variables, aka Options for Multiple Choice Questions
Statistical term that refers to a categorical variable with more than two possible categories or levels
Common in: Survey research ,healthcare, market research and education
Characteristics:

Categorical data: limited/distinct values or categories that are mutually exclusive
Always more than two options(binary)
Ordered and unordered (natural hiearchy)
Statistical analyses: e.g. logistic regression, cluster analysis for patterns and trends
Convertable to binary variables

Purpose:

Understanding complex phenomena: patterns and trends in the data collected
Provide insights to better categorization of data
Statistical analyses: Relationships between variables: e.g. logistic regression to predict probability
Market segmentation: e.g. customers to preference, behavior, demographic groups

title: Data, Data, Data, Collection Methodologies and Quantitative vs. Qualitative
text:
Polytomous Variable (Continued)
When to use Polytomous Variables

Measuring attitudes or perceptions: for more nuanced perceptions
Putting definitions on categorizzing data: greater variability
Analyzing relationships between variables: job satisfication & job performance
Need to capture complex phenomena

Limitations

Power of explanation limited by available options

e.g. satisfactory survey & number of enrolled students, what about change?

subjectivity from questionnaire design and interpretation of results
response bias
small sample sizes

calculating the appropriate size of population needed
amount of respondants needed to reach statistical significance (reject null hypothesis, not covered by current class, leverage sample size calculator online)

title: Data, Data, Data, Collection Methodologies and Quantitative vs. Qualitative
text:
Primary Data Collection: Designing Questionnaires
Face-to-face, paper-and-pencil or remote, make sure your data collected is: - well-organized and - easily accessible for analysis.
General rules for constructing a questionnaire:
Dos:

questions should be short and simple
provide clear navigation to avoid difficulty in reading and motivate answering
use positive sentences
add open-answer possibility after provideing listed answers
improve reliability by selecting appropriate words
explain importance of the questionnaire
order your questions to solicit the right answers (sensitive to follow concrete/innocuous ones)

Do-nots:

use more than one question (double-barreled) in one item
make assumptions for the respondents
lead the respondant to answers with clues, suggestions and hints

Mixture of interview and observation
Used to discover human behavior, attitudes and respondents facing a particular concept
6-12 people in each group with shared characteristics
Mediator aims to stimulate and discover the behavior of the participats and reasons for each behavior using the social dynamic of the group

title: Data, Data, Data, Collection Methodologies and Quantitative vs. Qualitative
text:
FGD: Strengths and Weaknesses
Strengths:

discover social, health and cultural concepts
literacy of individuals non-issue
suitable to explore complex subjects
useful to develop hypotheses

Weaknesses:

expensive and time-consuming
privacy risks
confined by readiness of facilitator/mediator
domination of limited individuals in focus group (Frechtling, 2002, Kabir, 2016)

Survey and questionnaire: What’s the difference?

Questionnaire is the written set of questions.
Survey is both the set of questions and the process of collecting, aggregating and analyzing the responses from those questions.

Good & Bad Survey Questions: Let’s try out how to conduct surveys
Context: Surveying respondants on their religious beliefs and life styles

How religious are you?

Avoid ambiguity
Avoid leading questions
Avoid lengthy surveys and very long responses
How will your initial questions influence answers to subsequent ones?
Think carefully about sampling techniques
Seek to achieve highest rate possible
Standardize administration procedures
Guarantee anonymity (or confidentiality at minimum)
Seek measures of reliability
Assess validity.

Merit and Challenges of working with Case Studies
Pros/Merits:

Combines the strengths of multiple research methods
Consider research from various time frame: past, present and future
Provide explanation about the changes and impacting factors that are not readily available

Cons/Challenges:

Complex processes, time consuming and expensive
No clear limit on when to stop collecting data
The assumption taken may not always be realistic or data tested in that context
Usually requires expert and trained conducting teams
Over-interpretation and over-generalizing issues can happen (Taherdoost, 2021)

title: Data, Data, Data, Collection Methodologies and Quantitative vs. Qualitative
text:
Let’s practice data collection/design concepts

Several years ago, a group of students at University of Central Arkansas conducted a study in which they observed the rate at which cars failed to stop at a campus stop sign and recorded whether the car had a student parking decal or a faculty/staff parking decal. This is obviously not fitting for Hong Kong context. Let’s perhaps picture a study of the rate of jay-walking at a traffic light instead - and record whether the pedestrian who crossed is a student/staff/tourist/local resident. Use what we have covered today to answer questions 1-7:


Which method of observation would be best? Justify your answer. Hint: back to participant/direct observations.
How would you schedule observations?
Define the categories of behavior that you would observe
Describe how you would optimize and measure the reliability of observations, including the use of independent observers and calculation of interobserver agreement.
Describe how you could use equipment for observation rather than human observers, what are the advantages and disadvantages?
Describe how you might use public records to answer the same research question. What might be some limitations of this approach
Describe how you might use a survey method to answer the same research question. What might be some limitations of this approach?

title: DESN2003: Reserach for Innovation
text:
Title:
Investigating User Feedback for Enhancing GenAI-Integrated Conversational Interfaces in HCI


Abstract
This study looks at how user feedback can help improve conversational interfaces that use generative AI (GenAI) in human-computer interaction (HCI). The idea is to explore both what users say and what their actions suggest about the interface’s design. We aim to understand if the interface meets users’ expectations and what improvements can be made. Early observations indicate that while users appreciate the advanced AI capabilities, there is some confusion regarding the AI’s decision-making process, which might be due to insufficient explanations in the design. The study will combine survey responses with usability testing data to offer recommendations for future improvements.



Literature Review
Human-computer interaction has been evolving over the past few decades, with a lot of focus on making systems more user-friendly. Early research by Norman (2013) showed that usability is the core of good design. More recent studies, however, have started to look at how GenAI can be integrated into these systems to make interactions more natural. For example, Lee and Park (2022) describe conversational agents that can mimic human dialogue, which seems promising but also raises questions about reliability and user trust.
Some researchers argue that the use of GenAI might actually hinder user experience if the technology does not align with user expectations. Johnson et al. (2023) point out that while GenAI can produce quick responses, these responses sometimes lack context, which may lead users to feel misunderstood. This study is important because it mixes descriptive observations—like noting the speed of the responses—with analytical questions about whether the speed compromises the quality of interactions.
There is a noticeable gap, though, in the literature when it comes to understanding how different user groups (novices versus experienced users) actually interact with these systems. Many studies provide a lot of descriptive data (e.g., error rates, response times) without delving into why users might behave in a certain way. This gap is significant because without analysis, we just have numbers without an understanding of the underlying issues.
It is also worth noting that some of the literature is a bit redundant. Many papers just restate that user feedback is important without explaining how to implement it effectively. This is something that our research intends to address by not only gathering descriptive data but also engaging in a deeper analysis of user comments and behavior during interactions with the system.



Methodology
To tackle the research questions, this study employs a mixed-methods approach, even though the approach might seem a bit scattered at first glance. The research is split into three phases.
Phase 1: Pre-Test Survey
- Participants: We plan to recruit about 30 undergraduate students, preferably with varying experiences in using conversational interfaces.
- Survey Design: The survey will ask participants about their familiarity with GenAI, their initial impressions of conversational agents, and any previous experiences with AI-based interfaces.
- Goal: This phase is meant to collect baseline data, which is crucial, even if it might seem a bit generic. The data will later be compared with what we observe during usability testing.
Phase 2: Usability Testing
- Test Setup: The usability tests will be conducted in a lab setting where participants interact with a prototype conversational interface. The interface is designed to simulate a GenAI-powered dialogue system, though there may be issues with its responsiveness.
- Task Scenarios: Participants will perform tasks like asking for help, checking information, and engaging in casual conversation. These tasks are designed to mimic real-life usage but might not capture every nuance of natural conversation.
- Data Collection: We will collect quantitative data such as task completion time and error rates, as well as qualitative data in the form of recorded verbal feedback and written comments.
- Analytical Focus: The analysis will focus on identifying common themes in the feedback. For example, if several users mention that the system’s responses seem “robotic” or “hard to follow,” we will consider whether the interface lacks sufficient context or explanation. This phase is both descriptive (measuring performance metrics) and analytical (interpreting feedback to suggest improvements).
Phase 3: Post-Test Survey and Group Discussion
- Post-Test Survey: After the usability testing, participants will complete a short survey asking for their impressions of the interface and suggestions for improvement.
- Group Discussion: A focus group will be held to discuss the usability test outcomes. The discussion will be semi-structured, allowing for both free-form feedback and guided questions about what worked and what did not.
- Data Analysis: We plan to use thematic analysis on the qualitative data to extract key issues. The intent is to correlate these themes with the quantitative data from Phase 2, though this may lead to some unexpected or messy findings that will need careful interpretation.



Diagnostic Reflection

Strengths Noted:

The writeup successfully combines descriptive details (e.g., the steps of the usability test) with analytical commentary (e.g., questioning why users find responses robotic).

There is a clear attempt to connect the literature with the research methodology.

Caveats and Areas for Improvement:

The language is sometimes repetitive, and the analytical parts are not always fully developed. For instance, the discussion on the gap in literature is somewhat superficial.

There is a mix of overly generic phrases (“data is crucial”) with more detailed analysis, which might confuse the reader about the depth of the research.

The structure could be tightened; some parts seem scattered, reflecting a common issue in student writing where descriptive and analytical elements are not clearly separated.


This sample serves as a diagnostic example. It demonstrates both the potential for blending descriptive and analytical writing and the common pitfalls—such as redundancy, superficial analysis, and structural disorganization—that you should work on when revising your own work.

section: Pros and Cons: Working as a Group vs. Individual
text:

losing control over showflow and

write the full report on one’s own and coming up with all questions that you’ll want to ask

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Descriptive vs. Analytical Writing
Welcome to today’s session on distinguishing between descriptive and analytical writing. Let’s enhance our academic writing skills together!

In this session, we’ll explore the key differences between descriptive and analytical writing, which are crucial for academic success, especially in fields like UI/UX and product design.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Activity: Identify the Writing Style
We’ll go through several examples. For each, determine if it’s descriptive or analytical. After your response, we’ll reveal the correct answer and discuss.

This interactive activity aims to help students practice distinguishing between descriptive and analytical writing through real examples.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 1: Question
“User engagement metrics have decreased by 20% over the past three months.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

This statement simply presents a fact without interpretation. Think: Does it explain why or how?

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 1: Answer
Answer: Descriptive
Explanation:
The sentence reports a fact (a 20% drop) without delving into any reasons or implications behind the metric change.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 2: Question
“Maslow’s hierarchy of needs is a psychological theory that arranges human needs in a pyramid, with physiological needs at the base and self-actualization at the top.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

It describes the theory’s structure, but it doesn’t critically assess its limitations or context.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 2: Answer
Answer: Descriptive
Explanation:
While it explains the pyramid structure, it does not analyze or critique the theory’s applicability or limitations across different cultures.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 3: Question
“The experiment demonstrated that plants exposed to sunlight grew faster than those kept in the shade.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

It reports the outcome of an experiment without explaining the underlying reasons.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 3: Answer
Answer: Descriptive
Explanation:
The statement provides an observation (faster growth with sunlight) without discussing the process or significance of the finding.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 4: Question
“In Shakespeare’s ‘Macbeth,’ Lady Macbeth’s manipulation of her husband’s actions serves as a commentary on the corrupting power of unchecked ambition and challenges traditional gender roles in Shakespearean society.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

This statement goes beyond merely describing; it interprets the role of Lady Macbeth to reveal broader themes.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 4: Answer
Answer: Analytical
Explanation:
It not only identifies Lady Macbeth’s influence but also interprets her actions as a critique of societal norms, thus offering analytical insight.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 5: Question
“Survey results show that 60% of respondents prefer online shopping over in-store shopping.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

Consider if the sentence just states the data or explores reasons behind the preference.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 5: Answer
Answer: Descriptive
Explanation:
It presents a statistic without discussing why users might prefer online shopping or its implications for consumer behavior.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 6: Question
“While the interface layout includes a navigation bar, a content area, and a footer, this design might impede user engagement if it fails to prioritize the most critical user tasks, suggesting a need for a more dynamic, behavior-driven layout.”
Question:
Is this statement descriptive or analytical?

Notice how this sentence not only describes the interface components but also evaluates their impact on user engagement.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Example 6: Answer
Answer: Analytical
Explanation:
The statement goes beyond description by assessing the potential drawbacks of the layout and suggesting improvements based on user behavior.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Key Takeaways

Descriptive vs. Analytical:

Descriptive writing states facts or observations.

Analytical writing explains the significance, reasoning, and implications behind those facts.

Depth of Analysis:

Effective academic writing connects evidence with critical interpretation.

Always ask: “Why is this important?” and “What does this mean for the overall argument?”

Practical Strategies for Improvement:

Peer Review: Leverage feedback from classmates to identify areas lacking analysis.

Reverse Outlining: Break down your text to pinpoint descriptive versus analytical sections.

Continuous Revision:

Use these insights to refine your drafts, deepening your analysis and improving clarity.



These key points emphasize the critical differences between descriptive and analytical writing. Remember, the goal is to transform simple statements into a compelling argument by integrating evidence, interpretation, and reflection. Use peer review and reverse outlining as tools to uncover and address any gaps in your analysis.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Enhancing Your Analytical Writing
Objective:
- Develop your analytical writing skills by examining and revising your literature review or methodology sections.
- Engage in collaborative activities to practice critical analysis.
Today’s Activities:
1. Peer Review: In pairs, analyze each other’s writing using guided questions.
2. Reverse Outlining: Break down a text (yours or a provided sample) to identify strengths and gaps.

In this session, we’ll focus on moving beyond descriptive writing into deep, analytical writing. You have the option to work on your own work or use a sample provided by me.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Stage 1: Peer Review Activity
Time: 25 minutes
Instructions:

Pair Up: Find a partner in the room.
Exchange Materials: Share your literature review or methodology section (or use the provided sample).
Guided Review: Use these questions as you read your partner’s work:

Thesis & Argument:

Is the thesis clear and arguable?
Does the argument show critical evaluation rather than just stating facts?

Use of Evidence:

Is evidence well integrated and analyzed?
Does the writer explain the significance of each piece of evidence?

Structure & Flow:

Are the ideas presented logically?
Do transitions connect the analysis throughout the paper?



Goal:
- Provide constructive feedback focused on deepening the analysis.

As you review, think critically: Are the claims supported by analysis or just stated? Focus on suggesting ways to integrate evidence and clarify your argument.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Stage 2: Reverse Outlining Exercise
Time: 25 minutes
Instructions:

Choose Your Text: Pick a section from the previously worked-upon example you looked at (4-5 paragraphs max).
Number Each Paragraph: Number the paragraphs in the margin for clarity.
Summarize Each Paragraph: In one sentence, capture the main idea or argument of each paragraph.
Evaluate the Outline:

Does each summary contribute to your overall argument?

Identify any parts that are merely descriptive rather than analytical.

Plan Revisions: Mark paragraphs that need more critical insight or better integration of evidence.

Goal:
- Reveal the structure and flow of your argument and present to each other. - Identify areas where you can add deeper analysis or clarity.

Reverse outlining is a fantastic way to “step back” and see if your paragraphs are advancing your argument. Look for any gaps where analysis is missing, and consider how you can connect ideas more cohesively.

title: DESN2003 | Research for Innovation
text:
Reflection & Discussion
Discussion Questions:
- What new insights did you gain about your own writing from these activities?
- How can the feedback from your peer review inform your revisions?
- What specific changes will you make to improve the analytical depth of your paper?
Next Steps:
- Revise your draft based on the insights and feedback received. - Schedule a follow-up session if you need additional support on integrating analytical writing techniques.

Feel free to share your reflections with the class. This discussion will help you and your peers learn from one another’s experiences and insights. Remember, the aim is not just to correct, but to deepen your understanding of analytical writing.

import json
from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS

# Load the transcripts from the JSON file
with open('transcripts.json', 'r') as f:
    transcripts = json.load(f)

# Combine all transcript texts into one large string
all_text = " ".join([entry['text'] for entry in transcripts])

# Prepare a list of stopwords (common words like 'the', 'and', 'I' that we exclude)
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)

# Create and generate the word cloud
wc = WordCloud(width=600, height=400, background_color="white", stopwords=stopwords)
wc.generate(all_text)

# Display the word cloud
plt.figure(figsize=(8,5))
plt.imshow(wc, interpolation='bilinear')
plt.axis("off")
plt.title("Word Cloud of Interview Transcripts")
plt.show()

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Last Week: Your Instagram Feature Ideas
text:
Last Week: Your Instagram Feature Ideas
Remember the persona exercise?


You picked someone you know
Identified what they love and hate about Instagram
Proposed a new feature Instagram is “dying for”






Today’s Big Question


How do you know your feature idea is actually needed—and not just a clever assumption?





Quick recall to activate prior knowledge
Set up the tension: intuition vs. evidence
This frames the whole session

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Quick Pulse Check
Turn to a neighbor (2 minutes):


What feature did you propose last week?
What made you think Instagram needs this?



We’ll come back to these ideas throughout today’s session.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Challenge
You’ve identified a gap. Now let’s stress-test it.



Your Task (15 minutes, in pairs)


Pick ONE of your feature ideas and work through these questions:





The Gap: What specific user problem or frustration does this feature solve?
The Evidence: What makes you believe this gap exists? (Personal experience? Observations? Something you read?)
The Assumption Check: Could this just be your preference, or is it widespread?
The Landscape: Does this feature exist in a competitor app (TikTok, BeReal, Snapchat)? If yes, why might Instagram not have it? If no, why might that be?
The Validation: If you had to prove this gap is real, what would you do?




Circulate and listen to conversations
Note interesting approaches to bring up in debrief
Push them: “How do you KNOW that’s true?”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Debrief: What Did You Discover?
Let’s hear from a few groups:


What gap did you identify?
How confident are you that it’s real?
What would you need to validate it?






Notice Something?


You just did research thinking—without formal methods. Now let’s name what you were doing.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Planting Seeds: Methods You Used Without Knowing
text:
Planting Seeds: Methods You Used Without Knowing
When you worked through that case study, you were already doing research:


What You Did:

Recalled how someone uses Instagram
Noticed their frustrations
Compared to your own experience
Thought about “would others feel this way?”
Imagined how to test your idea


The Formal Name:

Ethnographic observation (watching behavior)
Pain point analysis (identifying friction)
Comparative analysis (self vs. others)
Generalizability question (sample → population)
Research design thinking (validation strategy)







The Point


Research isn’t something foreign—it’s systematic thinking you already do naturally. Today we formalize it.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Validation Methods You Proposed
When asked “how would you prove this gap is real?”, you likely suggested:


“Ask more people” → That’s a survey or interview
“Watch how people actually use it” → That’s observational research or usability testing
“Look at app reviews/complaints” → That’s secondary research / content analysis
“Check if competitors have this feature” → That’s competitive analysis
“Test it with a small group” → That’s prototype testing or A/B testing



These are all legitimate research methodologies. The question is: which one fits your question?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: From Gut Feeling to Systematic Inquiry
text:
From Gut Feeling to Systematic Inquiry


Without Frameworks

“I think users want this”
“My friend complained about it”
“It makes sense to me”
“I’ve seen people struggle”

Problem: Confirmation bias, small samples, untested assumptions

With Frameworks

“User interviews revealed a pattern”
“Survey data shows 67% experience this”
“Competitive analysis found a gap”
“A/B test showed 40% improvement”

Strength: Systematic, defensible, scalable






The Shift


Research frameworks don’t replace intuition—they validate and strengthen it.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: The Big Picture: Types of Research
text:
The Big Picture: Types of Research
Applied vs. Fundamental


Basic (Fundamental) Research

Expanding knowledge without immediate practical application
“How do humans process visual information?”
Builds theory and understanding

Your Instagram work: Not this (you have a practical goal)

Applied Research

Solving specific, real-world problems
“How can we reduce checkout abandonment?”
Directly informs design decisions

Your Instagram work: This one! You’re solving a real user problem.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Quantitative vs. Qualitative


Quantitative Research

Numbers and statistics
“How many users experience this?”
“What’s the conversion rate?”
Measures magnitude and frequency

Your case study: “Would others feel this way?” → needs quantitative validation

Qualitative Research

Non-numerical data (text, interviews, observations)
“Why do users feel frustrated?”
“How do they describe the problem?”
Explores depth and meaning

Your case study: Understanding the persona’s frustrations → qualitative insight






Mixed Methods


Often the most powerful approach: Qualitative to understand the “why” → Quantitative to measure the “how many”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Why Classification Matters


Choosing the right method for your research question
Common language to discuss and compare approaches
Distinguish fads from real trends (is this a genuine gap or a passing complaint?)






Back to Your Feature Idea


If you want to validate your Instagram feature:

Qualitative first: Interview 5-10 users to understand the problem deeply
Quantitative second: Survey 100+ users to see if the pattern holds broadly

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What Is a Research Gap?
A research gap is an area where no or little information is available


It represents an opportunity for new research and discovery
It’s where innovation lives



Types of gaps:


A concept or idea that hasn’t been studied at all
Existing research is outdated and needs updating
A specific population hasn’t been well studied
A context hasn’t been explored (e.g., Instagram for Gen Z creators vs. casual users)




Connect directly to their case study: “The gap you identified in Instagram? That’s a research gap.”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Your Instagram Feature = A Research Gap Hypothesis
text:
Your Instagram Feature = A Research Gap Hypothesis



Think About It


When you proposed your feature, you were essentially saying:
“There’s a gap between what users need and what Instagram currently offers.”




But is it a real gap?


Maybe Instagram already tried it and it failed (you don’t know the history)
Maybe only a small subset of users want it (your sample is biased)
Maybe there’s a technical/business reason it doesn’t exist
Maybe it exists and you just haven’t found it




Research helps you answer: Is this gap real, significant, and addressable?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Methods to Identify & Validate Research Gaps
text:
Methods to Identify & Validate Research Gaps


For Academic Research:

Systematic literature review
“Suggestions for future research” sections
Heavily-cited seminal works
Databases: Web of Science, SAGE, Research Rabbit
Consultation with experts


For Product/Design Research:

User interviews & pain point analysis
App store reviews & social media complaints
Competitive analysis
Usage analytics & drop-off data
Customer support ticket patterns







The Parallel


Academic researchers read papers to find gaps. Product researchers talk to users and analyze data. Same goal, different sources.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: The Scientific Approach to Design Decisions
text:
The Scientific Approach to Design Decisions
A/B Testing: A method to compare two versions of a variable to determine which performs better


Origin: Derived from Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) in scientific research
Application: Widely used in product development, marketing, and user experience design






Connection to Your Case Study


If your Instagram feature got built, A/B testing would be how they’d validate it actually works better than the current design.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Key Concepts


Control Group: The existing version (A)
Treatment Group: The new version being tested (B)
Randomization: Users randomly assigned to A or B
Metrics: Predefined measures of success
Statistical Significance: Ensuring results aren’t due to chance








Remember


The only difference between A and B should be the element you’re testing!

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The A/B Testing Process


Hypothesis: Formulate a testable prediction
Design: Create version A and B
Implement: Set up the test environment
Collect Data: Run the test and gather results
Analyze: Determine statistical significance
Conclude: Make data-driven decisions

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What do you know about click through rate?
Clicks/Views * 100 - Effectiveness - Placement & Visibility - User Experience Improvements - Performance Benchmarking

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Case Study - Button Color Test
Hypothesis: A green “Learn More” button will increase conversions compared to the current blue button.
Results:

Version A (Blue): 100 sign-ups from 1000 views (10% conversion)
Version B (Green): 150 sign-ups from 1000 views (15% conversion)
50% increase in conversion rate, statistically significant (p < 0.05)




Your Feature Idea


How would you A/B test it? What would “success” look like in metrics?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Quantitative Methods (The Numbers)


Measuring & Comparing:

Survey: Collect data from many users
Experimental: Test cause-and-effect
A/B Testing (RCTs): Compare two versions
Correlation: Find relationships between variables


Analyzing Patterns:

Data Mining & Analytics: Discover patterns in large datasets
Longitudinal Analysis: Track changes over time
Meta-Analysis: Combine results from multiple studies







For Your Instagram Feature


Survey could validate how widespread the problem is. A/B testing could measure if your solution works.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Qualitative Methods (The Why)


Understanding People:

Interviews: Deep conversations with users
Ethnography: Immerse in user’s environment
Case Study: In-depth analysis of specific situation
Phenomenology: Understand lived experiences


Analyzing Content:

Content Analysis: Systematically analyze text/media
Grounded Theory: Build theory from data
Narrative Analysis: Explore personal stories







For Your Instagram Feature


Interviews would help you understand WHY users are frustrated. Ethnography could reveal how they actually use the app (vs. how they say they do).

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Mixed Methods: Best of Both Worlds
text:
Mixed Methods: Best of Both Worlds
When you need both depth (qualitative) and scale (quantitative):


Sequential Explanatory: Quantitative first, then qualitative to explain
Sequential Exploratory: Qualitative first, then quantitative to validate
Concurrent Triangulation: Both at once, compare results






The Instagram Approach



Qualitative: Interview 10 users about their frustrations (find patterns)
Quantitative: Survey 500 users to see if patterns hold (validate scale)
Experimental: A/B test the feature with a subset (measure impact)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Exercise: Classify Your Research Approach
Return to your Instagram feature idea (5 minutes):


Is validating your feature applied or fundamental research?
Would you start with qualitative or quantitative methods? Why?
What specific method would you use first?
How would you know if the gap is real vs. assumed?






Share Out


Be ready to explain your reasoning to the class.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Scenarios: What Type of Research?

What type of research is this and why?



A team conducts eye-tracking studies to understand how users interact with a new stories feature.

Applied, Quantitative, Experimental/Observational

A UX researcher analyzes the evolution of navigation patterns in mobile apps over the past decade.

Applied, Mixed Methods, Longitudinal/Content Analysis

A startup runs A/B tests on their e-commerce checkout process.

Applied, Quantitative, Experimental (RCT)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Research Gap Practice: VUI Abstracts
Find the research gap sentence, then identify the actual gap:

Abstract 1: “Voice User Interfaces (VUIs) are increasingly prevalent in smart home devices, yet their accessibility for users with visual and motor impairments remains understudied. We conducted a mixed-methods study…”


Abstract 2: “Our findings indicate that while VUIs can enhance independence for older adults, current designs often do not adequately address age-related changes in cognition, hearing, and speech production…”


Abstract 3: “However, current VUI design frameworks do not adequately account for these cultural variations, potentially leading to reduced usability…”


Overarching gap: VUI design lacks consideration for diverse user populations (accessibility, age, culture)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Today’s Key Takeaways


Research thinking is natural—you already do it. Frameworks make it systematic.
Research gaps are opportunities—your feature idea is a hypothesis about a gap.
Applied vs. Fundamental tells you the goal; Quant vs. Qual tells you the approach.
Start qualitative to understand the “why,” then go quantitative to measure the “how many.”
Validation transforms assumptions into insights—that’s the power of research.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: The Bridge: From Instinct to Evidence
text:
The Bridge: From Instinct to Evidence


Week 1: You had an instinct

“Instagram needs this feature”
Based on observing someone you know
A hypothesis waiting to be tested


Week 2: You learned to validate it

Is this a real research gap?
What methods would test it?
How do you move from assumption to evidence?




Next Week: We’ll dive into Literature Review—how to find what’s already known so you don’t reinvent the wheel.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Assignment: Write Your Own Abstract
For the upcoming two weeks:
Draft an abstract for your research proposal that includes:


The problem/gap you’re addressing
Why it matters
Your proposed approach (methods)
Expected contribution








Hint



Your Instagram feature idea could be the seed for this. What gap does it address? How would you research it?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Questions?

Let’s discuss!

Office hours: By appointment
Next week: Literature Review—finding what’s already known


Encourage questions about methods
Remind them the abstract assignment builds on today
Connect to next week’s lit review





DESN2003 Research for Innovation

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Question We’re Leaving Open



Think About This Before Next Week


When you checked “does this exist in a competitor app?”—how thorough was that search?

Did you check all competitors, or just the ones you know?
Did you look at academic research on similar features?
Did you find out if Instagram tried this before and it failed?
Do you know what the state of the art is in this space?





The uncomfortable truth: Your “gap” might not be a gap at all—you just haven’t looked hard enough yet.


Next week: How to systematically map what’s already known—so your innovation is actually new.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Remember the persona exercise?


You picked someone you know
Identified what they love and hate about Instagram
Proposed a new feature Instagram is “dying for”


. . .






Today’s Big Question



How do you know your feature idea is actually needed—and not just a clever assumption?




Quick recall to activate prior knowledge
Set up the tension: intuition vs. evidence
This frames the whole session






Turn to a neighbor (2 minutes):


What feature did you propose last week?
What made you think Instagram needs this?


. . .
We’ll come back to these ideas throughout today’s session.
