title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Submit Your Document 0 next week!
Length: ≤ 500 words

Expand beyond what you’ve written before
Think critically at how much better you could’ve written this

Style: Extended Abstract

Should contain what you normally see in normal abstracts
Can contain additional bullet points and outlines on what do you propose to do next or potential outcomes




Hint


Your Instagram feature idea could be the seed for this—but you’ll need to know what’s already out there first.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
How Thorough Was Your Search?
Last week, you checked if your Instagram feature exists in competitor apps.

But did you really know the landscape?


Did you check all competitors, or just the ones you use?
Did you find out if Instagram tried this before and killed it?
Do you know why similar features succeeded or failed elsewhere?
Is there research on this type of feature?







The Risk


If you don’t map what exists, you might “innovate” something that already failed—or reinvent what already works.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Today’s Goal: Learn to Map the Landscape
text:
Today’s Goal: Learn to Map the Landscape


Industry Approach
Competitive Analysis

What do competitors offer?
What’s the feature history?
What do users say about existing solutions?
What have companies tried and abandoned?


Academic Approach
Literature Review

What does research say?
What theories explain user behavior?
What methods have been tested?
What gaps remain unstudied?







Both Serve the Same Goal


Know what exists before claiming your idea is new.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What Is Competitive Analysis?
A systematic examination of similar products/features to understand:


What exists: Features, approaches, solutions already in market
What works: Successful implementations and why
What failed: Abandoned features, pivots, user backlash
What’s missing: Gaps that remain unfilled






For Your Instagram Feature


Before proposing a “new” feature, you need to know: Has this been tried? Does it exist elsewhere? Why or why not?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: The Competitive Landscape for Social Media
text:
The Competitive Landscape for Social Media
Direct Competitors:


TikTok, Snapchat, BeReal, YouTube Shorts, X/Twitter, Threads, WeChat, LINE


Adjacent Products:


Pinterest (visual discovery), Discord (community), WhatsApp (messaging), Notion (sharing)


Historical Context:


Vine (dead), Google+ (dead), Clubhouse (declined), Periscope (absorbed)






The Graveyard Matters


Failed products and killed features tell you what didn’t work—often more valuable than successes.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Sources for Competitive Analysis


Product Intelligence:

App Store / Play Store (features, reviews, update history)
Product Hunt (launch announcements)
TechCrunch, The Verge, Wired (feature coverage)
Company blogs and newsrooms
Wayback Machine (historical snapshots)


User Sentiment:

App reviews (1-star reviews are gold)
Reddit communities (r/Instagram, r/socialmedia)
Twitter/X complaints and wishlists
YouTube reviews and comparisons
Designer/developer forums







Pro Tip


Search “[feature name] + failed” or “[app name] + removed feature” to find the graveyard.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Competitive Analysis Framework
For each competitor/feature, document:







Question
What to Look For




What is it?
Feature name, how it works, when launched


Who uses it?
Target users, use cases


How well does it work?
User reception, ratings, complaints


What’s the trajectory?
Growing? Stagnant? Killed?


Why does it matter for your idea?
Validates gap? Invalidates it? Inspires iteration?




This becomes your competitive landscape map—the foundation for knowing if your gap is real.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Quick Exercise: Map Your Feature’s Landscape (10 min)
text:
Quick Exercise: Map Your Feature’s Landscape (10 min)
In pairs, for your Instagram feature idea:


List 3 competitors that might have something similar
Do a quick search: Does this feature (or something close) exist?
If yes: How is it implemented? What do users say?
If no: Why might that be? (Technical? Strategic? No demand?)
What did you learn that changes your thinking?






Share Out


Be ready to report: Did your gap survive the competitive check?





Circulate and help with search strategies
Push them to look beyond obvious competitors
Note interesting findings for class discussion

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Debrief: What Did the Landscape Reveal?
text:
Debrief: What Did the Landscape Reveal?


Did anyone discover their feature already exists?
Did anyone find a failed attempt at something similar?
Did anyone’s gap get stronger after seeing what competitors lack?
What surprised you?






The Insight


Competitive analysis doesn’t kill ideas—it refines them. Now you know what to differentiate from.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Competitive Analysis Is Not Enough
You’ve mapped the product landscape. But there’s more:


Why do certain features succeed psychologically?
What theories explain user behavior in this space?
What research methods have been used to study this?
What do experts know that practitioners haven’t applied yet?






The Gap Between Industry and Academy


Companies move fast and often don’t read research. Academics study deeply but publish slowly. Your advantage: You can bridge both.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Literature Review: The Academic Landscape Map
text:
Literature Review: The Academic Landscape Map


Literature =
The body of knowledge in any discipline:

Theoretical frameworks
Empirical studies
Practical applications
Relevant investigations


Review =
Knowledge organized to show:

What’s known
What’s debated
What’s missing
Why YOUR study adds value







Think of It This Way


Competitive analysis maps products. Literature review maps knowledge.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Why Literature Review Matters


Understand the research landscape—what’s been studied, what hasn’t
Avoid repetitive work—don’t “discover” what’s already known
Build on existing theory—your work stands on others’ shoulders
Identify research gaps—where can YOU contribute?






Connection to Your Feature Idea


Maybe your feature addresses a gap that researchers have already identified but industry hasn’t solved yet. Literature review helps you find that.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Two Phases of Literature Review
Phase One: Catch-them-all


Identify all relevant publications within your problem space
Read/skim through and broaden your understanding
Critique how/why some are (not) adequate in what they claim



Phase Two: Write on Relevance


Synthesize findings into coherent writing
Present your own evaluation—both strengths and weaknesses
Create a roadmap showing how your work fits in

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What Literature Review Provides
A stock of:


Theories, ideas, explanations that frame your thinking
Record to check against for repetition
Methods, procedures, data sources suitable for your problem
Conclusions drawn in related studies



These become the building blocks for your own research design.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Common Sources of Literature


Academic Sources:

Peer-reviewed journals
Conference proceedings (CHI, DIS, CSCW for HCI/design)
Books and book chapters
Dissertations and theses
Systematic reviews


Professional Sources:

Industry reports (Nielsen Norman, Forrester)
White papers
Design case studies
Standards documents
Expert blogs (with caution)







Key Databases for Design Research


Google Scholar, ACM Digital Library, IEEE Xplore, JSTOR, Web of Science

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Reading for Relevance: The Process
For each source you find:
1. RELEVANCE? Gain general impression


What research question does it address?
How is it structured?
Was the problem tackled adequately?


2. HOW MIGHT IT HELP? Consider utility


Does it answer part of YOUR question?
Where are the key findings?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Reading for Relevance (Cont’d)
3. HOW DOES IT HELP? Read in depth


How well does it answer your question?
What are its limitations?


4. WRITE NOTES


Citation info (use Zotero, Mendeley)
Why it’s relevant to YOUR work
Key quotes or findings to reference






Precaution


Literature review is NOT relisting previous studies. It’s synthesizing them into YOUR argument.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Research Paper Examples
As seen on Moodle:


Hong Kong Construction Compression — quantitative focus
Fashion, Sustainability & Innovation — interview-heavy, qualitative



As you skim these, notice:


How do they frame what’s already known?
Where do they identify gaps?
How do they position their contribution?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What is an Annotated Bibliography?
A bridge between finding sources and writing the review:


Components:

Citation: Standard reference
Summary: Main ideas/findings
Evaluation: Strengths & limitations
Relevance: How it informs YOUR topic


Purpose:

Forces you to actually read (not just collect)
Helps you see patterns across sources
Becomes raw material for lit review writing

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Example Annotation
Citation: Smith, J. (2020). Designing Trust: UI Elements and User Experience. Journal of HCI.
Annotation: This study examines how minimalist UI designs impact user trust through A/B testing. It finds that simplified layouts reduce cognitive load and increase user confidence.

Strengths: Robust methodology and clear data analysis.
Limitations: Focuses solely on e-commerce, limiting broader applicability.
Relevance: Offers empirical support for design decisions in UI/UX, aligning with our research question on trust-building features.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Your Mission (20 minutes)
Search for academic/professional sources related to YOUR Instagram feature idea.

In groups of 3-4:

Define search terms based on your feature (e.g., “social media content curation,” “user-generated playlists,” “algorithmic transparency”)
Use Google Scholar, ACM DL, or industry sources
Find 3+ diverse sources (mix of academic and professional)
For each: Record title, author, year, source type
Note briefly: Why might this be relevant?






Stuck?


Think about the underlying problem your feature solves, not the feature itself. What’s the user need? The behavior? The frustration?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Search Strategy Tips


Keyword Strategies:

Start broad, then narrow
Use synonyms (engagement, retention, stickiness)
Combine terms: “social media” + “user trust”
Try problem-focused: “doom scrolling” + “design intervention”


Source Strategies:

Check “cited by” for newer work
Check references for foundational work
Look for survey/review papers (cover lots of ground)
Search author names who publish in your area

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Annotated Bibliography Task
For your best 2 sources, write a 100-150 word annotation:


Summary: What does the source say?
Evaluation: How reliable and useful is it?
Relevance: How does it connect to YOUR feature idea?






The Payoff


This becomes the start of your Document 0’s literature foundation.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Landscape Check
You’ve now explored:


Week 2: Is the gap real? Does it exist in competitors?
Week 3: What does research say? What’s been studied?



Reflection questions:


Has your understanding of the “gap” changed?
Did you find research that supports your instinct?
Did you find something that challenges it?
Has your feature idea evolved?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Three Outcomes


Gap Confirmed ✓

Neither competitors nor research have addressed this
You found supporting evidence for the underlying problem
Next: Design your research to fill it


Gap Refined ↻

Similar things exist, but with important differences
Research exists, but not in this context
Next: Sharpen what makes yours unique


Gap Invalidated ✗

This already exists or has been studied extensively
Next: Pivot to a new angle, or go deeper than existing work




All three outcomes are valuable. Research isn’t about being “right”—it’s about knowing the truth.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Wrap-Up: Share & Discuss
Each group presents:


One annotated source you found
How it changed (or confirmed) your thinking about your feature idea



Discussion:

What surprised you in the literature?
How does this connect to competitive analysis?
What next steps would you take?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Key Takeaways


Competitive analysis maps the product landscape—what exists, what failed, what’s missing
Literature review maps the knowledge landscape—what’s studied, what’s theorized, what’s unknown
Both serve innovation—you can’t claim “new” without knowing what’s old
Your gap evolves—research refines instinct into insight
This is iterative—you’ll return to the literature throughout your project

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Next Week: Research Questions



The Journey So Far



Week 1: You had an instinct (feature idea)
Week 2: You learned to validate gaps (is it real?)
Week 3: You mapped the landscape (what exists?)
Week 4: How do you turn this into a researchable question?





Your gap is becoming clearer. Now we need to make it specific, focused, and answerable.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Reminder: Document 0 Due Next Week


≤ 500 words extended abstract
Include: Problem, gap, proposed approach, potential outcomes
Use what you learned today to ground it in the landscape





Pro Tip


Reference at least 2-3 sources from your scavenger hunt. Show you’ve done the landscape work.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Questions?

Let’s discuss!

Office hours: By appointment
Next week: Research Questions—making your gap researchable


Encourage questions about search strategies
Remind them to keep building their annotated bibliography
Connect today’s work to Document 0





DESN2003 Research for Innovation

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What Is an Extended Abstract?
An extended abstract is not a summary of a paper you haven’t written yet.
It’s a pitch for your research:


What problem are you investigating?
Why does it matter (to you, to the field, to the world)?
What’s your angle or approach?
What might you find or contribute?






Think of It As…


A movie trailer for your research. You’re convincing someone it’s worth watching—without spoiling the ending (because you don’t know it yet).

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Extended Abstract: The Structure
≤500 words. Plain text. No citations needed.


What to include:

The Problem (2-3 sentences)

What issue are you investigating?

Why It Matters (2-3 sentences)

Personal significance + broader relevance

The Gap (1-2 sentences)

What’s missing or understudied?




Your Approach (2-3 sentences)

How will you investigate this?

Potential Contribution (1-2 sentences)

What might we learn?

Next Steps (optional)

Bullet points on what you’ll do next

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: What Makes a Strong Extended Abstract?
text:
What Makes a Strong Extended Abstract?


Do this:

Be specific about the problem
Show genuine curiosity
Scope appropriately (not too broad, not too narrow)
Connect personal interest to broader significance
Be honest about what you don’t know yet


Avoid this:

Vague topics (“I want to study sustainability”)
Just describing what without why
Overpromising results you can’t deliver
Trying to sound “academic” at the expense of clarity
Including citations (save those for Doc 0.1)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Example: From Instagram Feature to Extended Abstract
text:
Example: From Instagram Feature to Extended Abstract



Your Instagram idea could become Doc 0


Feature idea: “A ‘slow feed’ mode that limits scrolling to reduce anxiety”
Extended abstract seed:
Social media platforms optimize for engagement, often at the expense of user wellbeing. Instagram users report feeling anxious after extended scrolling sessions, yet the app provides no built-in tools to moderate consumption. This creates a gap between user needs (mindful usage) and platform design (maximized engagement). I propose to investigate how design interventions—specifically, intentional friction like scroll limits or “slow feed” modes—might reduce user anxiety without eliminating engagement entirely. Through user interviews and prototype testing, this research could contribute design principles for ethical engagement features…

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Your Task: Doc 0 Due Week 4
For the next two weeks:


Choose a topic you’re genuinely curious about
Draft your extended abstract (≤500 words)
Use the structure: Problem → Significance → Gap → Approach → Contribution
Submit by Tuesday, Feb 10, 12:00 PM noon






Starting Point


Your Instagram feature idea could be the seed—or pivot to something else entirely. What matters is that YOU find it interesting.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Where We’ve Been


Week 1
You had an instinct

Proposed a feature idea
Identified what users love/hate


Week 2
You validated the gap

Is this real or assumed?
What methods could test it?


Week 3
You mapped the landscape

Competitive analysis
Literature review
What’s already known?







Today’s Challenge


You know there’s a gap. But “there’s a gap” isn’t a research project.
How do you turn that gap into a question you can actually answer?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Today’s Roadmap


Doc 0 Reflection — Common patterns and feedback
What Makes a Research Question? — Anatomy of a good RQ
Types of Research Questions — Descriptive, relational, causal
Scoping Your Question — Not too broad, not too narrow
Activity: Refine YOUR Research Question
Looking Ahead — From question to method (Doc 0.1)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:


Articulate the difference between a topic, a gap, and a research question
Formulate a clear, focused research question from your identified gap
Evaluate whether a research question is answerable within your constraints
Scope a question appropriately (not too broad, not too narrow)

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Your Extended Abstracts: What We Saw
text:
Your Extended Abstracts: What We Saw
The Good:


Genuine curiosity about topics that matter to you
Clear problem identification in many cases
Personal connection to the research area



The Patterns to Address:


Topic ≠ Question — Many abstracts describe an area but don’t ask something specific
Gap ≠ Question — “This hasn’t been studied” isn’t the same as “What happens when…?”
Scope issues — Some too broad (“sustainability in design”), some too narrow
Over-promising — Claims that can’t be supported in one semester

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Progression: Topic → Gap → Question


Topic
An area of interest
“Social media and mental health”

Too broad to research
Could go anywhere
Not actionable


Gap
Something missing in the landscape
“Little research on how design interventions reduce Instagram-related anxiety”

More focused
Shows what’s missing
But still not a question


Research Question
A specific, answerable inquiry
“How do intentional friction features (like scroll limits) affect reported anxiety levels in young adult Instagram users?”

Specific
Answerable
Testable







Your Task Today


Move from gap → question. Make it specific enough to answer.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Anatomy of a Good Research Question
text:
Anatomy of a Good Research Question
A strong research question is:


FINER Criteria

Feasible — Can you actually do this?
Interesting — Do you (and others) care?
Novel — Does it add something new?
Ethical — Can it be done responsibly?
Relevant — Does it matter to the field?


Practical Checks

Can you answer it in one semester?
Do you have access to the data/people needed?
Is it specific enough to guide your methods?
Is it open enough to allow discovery?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Good vs. Bad Research Questions


Weak Questions

“What is sustainable design?”

Too broad, definitional

“Is Instagram bad for mental health?”

Too binary, too broad

“Why don’t people recycle?”

Too vague, no focus

“Will my app be successful?”

Not researchable



Strong Questions

“How do material choices affect user perception of sustainability in product packaging?”

Specific, testable

“What design features correlate with reduced self-reported anxiety in social media apps?”

Focused, measurable

“What barriers do HK residents cite for recycling participation?”

Bounded, answerable

“How do users perceive the usefulness of [specific feature] in [context]?”

Evaluable

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Question Formulation Framework
Start with your gap, then build the question:


Who is the population? (e.g., “young adult Instagram users”)
What is the phenomenon? (e.g., “intentional friction features”)
Where is the context? (e.g., “in daily social media use”)
When is the timeframe? (e.g., “over a two-week period”)
How/What is the inquiry? (e.g., “affect reported anxiety levels”)



Template:

“How does [phenomenon] affect/influence/relate to [outcome] among [population] in [context]?”


“What [factors/features/experiences] contribute to [outcome] for [population]?”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Three Main Types


Descriptive
What is happening?

Maps a phenomenon
Documents experiences
Establishes baseline

Example: “What are the main frustrations HK design students report when using AI tools for coursework?”
Methods: Surveys, interviews, observation

Relational
What goes with what?

Explores associations
Identifies patterns
Doesn’t prove causation

Example: “Is there a relationship between time spent on Instagram and self-reported productivity among students?”
Methods: Correlational surveys, analytics

Causal
Does X cause Y?

Tests interventions
Requires control
Strongest claims

Example: “Does implementing a ‘slow feed’ feature reduce anxiety compared to standard feed?”
Methods: Experiments, A/B tests

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Matching Question Type to Your Project
text:
Matching Question Type to Your Project



For a One-Semester Project


Descriptive and relational questions are usually most feasible.
Causal questions require controlled experiments, which may be difficult to set up in your timeframe. But you can do exploratory work that suggests causal relationships.




Think about your Doc 0 topic:


What type of question are you asking?
Is it descriptive (what’s happening)?
Is it relational (what correlates)?
Is it causal (what causes what)?
Is the question type realistic for your resources?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Goldilocks Problem


Too Broad
“How does technology affect design?”

Can’t answer in a lifetime
No clear method
No clear outcome

Result: Paralysis

Too Narrow
“Does the color blue on this specific button increase clicks by 3% on Tuesdays?”

Trivial findings
Limited contribution
Who cares?

Result: So what?

Just Right
“How do color choices in CTA buttons affect conversion rates in e-commerce checkout flows?”

Specific enough to study
Broad enough to matter
Clear path to method

Result: Actionable insight

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Scoping Dimensions
Use these to narrow or broaden your question:



Dimension
Broader
Narrower




Population
“Users”
“HK university students aged 18-24”


Context
“Social media”
“Instagram Stories feature”


Timeframe
“Over time”
“During a 2-week study period”


Geography
“Globally”
“In Hong Kong”


Phenomenon
“User engagement”
“Double-tap behavior on posts”







Rule of Thumb


If you can’t imagine how you’d collect data to answer it, it’s probably too broad. If the answer seems obvious or trivial, it’s probably too narrow.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Exercise: Scope Check
Which of these is better scoped? Why?


“How does social media affect teenagers?”

Too broad: which platform? which teens? affect what?

“How does Instagram’s Explore algorithm affect content discovery satisfaction among HK university students?”

Better: specific platform, specific population, specific outcome

“Does the third post in Instagram Explore get more engagement than the fourth post?”

Too narrow: trivial, limited insight

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Your Task (20 minutes)
Working individually or in pairs:


Start with your Doc 0 topic/gap (or the idea you’re considering)
Draft a research question using this format:

“How does [X] affect/relate to [Y] among [population] in [context]?”
OR “What [factors] contribute to [outcome] for [population]?”

Check your question against:

Is it specific enough? (Can you imagine collecting data?)
Is it broad enough? (Does the answer matter?)
Is it feasible? (Can you do this in one semester?)
What type is it? (Descriptive/Relational/Causal)

Prepare to share: Your question + one concern you have about it

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Peer Feedback (10 minutes)
Share your question with a neighbor. Give feedback:


Can you understand the question on first reading?
Is it too broad or too narrow?
What method might answer this? (If you can’t imagine one, it may be too vague)
What’s one way to make it sharper?






Feedback Frames



“I think the question is clear, but I’m not sure how you’d measure [X]…”
“Could you narrow the population to make it more feasible?”
“What if you focused on [specific aspect] instead of [broad area]?”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Debrief: Let’s Hear Some Questions


What questions did you come up with?
What was hardest about formulating the question?
How did peer feedback help?






Remember


Your research question will evolve. The literature review (Doc 0.1) often reveals that your question needs adjusting. That’s normal and expected.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
From Question to Method
Once you have a clear research question, you can ask:


What data would answer this? (numbers? words? observations?)
Who has this data? (users? databases? you need to collect it?)
How would you get it? (surveys? interviews? experiments?)
What would “an answer” look like? (statistics? themes? comparison?)



This is exactly what Doc 0.1 (Literature Review) prepares you for—and what Doc 0.2 (Collecting Evidence) will execute.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Research Question Cascade



Your Question Shapes Everything


Research Question ↓
Literature Review — What’s already known about this question?
Methodology — How will I answer this question?
Data Collection — What evidence addresses this question?
Analysis — What does the evidence say?
Conclusion — Did I answer the question?



A well-formed question makes every subsequent step clearer.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Upcoming Assessments


Just Submitted
Doc 0: Extended Abstract

Feedback will be released soon
Use it to refine your question
Don’t panic if you need to adjust


Coming Up
Doc 0.1: Literature Review

Due: Week 6 (Mar 3)
Now that you have a question, search for what’s already known
Your lit review should help you refine the question further







Next Week: Methods I


We’ll cover qualitative research methods—interviews, observations, ethnography. Start thinking: What method fits YOUR question?

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
What We Learned Today


Topic ≠ Gap ≠ Question — A research question is specific and answerable, not just an area of interest
Good questions are FINER — Feasible, Interesting, Novel, Ethical, Relevant
Three types of questions — Descriptive (what?), Relational (what correlates?), Causal (what causes?)
Scope matters — Not too broad (can’t answer), not too narrow (doesn’t matter)
Your question shapes everything — It determines your methods, data, and what counts as an answer
Questions evolve — It’s okay to refine as you learn more from the literature

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Bridge: Where We’re Going


Today (Week 4)
You learned to formulate a research question

From gap to inquiry
Specific and answerable
Guides your methodology


Next Week (Week 5)
You’ll learn qualitative methods

Interviews, observations, ethnography
How to collect rich, descriptive data
Which method fits your question?




The semester arc continues:
Instinct → Gap → Landscape → Question → Methods → Evidence → Analysis → Paper

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Questions?

Let’s discuss!

Office hours: By appointment
Next week: Methods I — Qualitative Research


Encourage questions about formulating RQs
Remind them Doc 0.1 builds on today’s work
The question they formulate today guides their lit review search





DESN2003 Research for Innovation

title: DESN2003 Weeks 4-12: Fix List
text:

title: DESN2003 Lecture Template & Checklist
text:
A consistent structure for all weekly lectures to ensure students feel they’re learning solid, connected content.






Title slide with week number, topic title, and subtitle that hints at the “why”
Callback/Connection to previous week (1 slide)

“Last week we learned X. Today we build on that by…”
Reinforces the throughline

Today’s Roadmap (1 slide)

3-5 bullet points of what will be covered
Non-incremental so students see the full agenda

Learning Objectives (can combine with roadmap or separate)

“By the end of this session, you will be able to…”
3-4 concrete, actionable objectives






Colored section headers ({background-color="#HEXCODE"}) to visually segment major topics
Callout boxes for key concepts:

.callout-note for definitions/information
.callout-tip for practical advice
.callout-warning for common pitfalls
.callout-important for critical points

Two-column layouts (::: {.columns}) for comparisons, parallel concepts
Concrete examples tied to student context (design, Instagram throughline, their own research)
Visuals/diagrams where appropriate (not just text)





Clear instructions with time allocation
Connection to concepts just taught
Deliverable - what should students produce or discuss?
Debrief slide - what did we learn from this activity?





Reference student’s own research project at least once

“How does this apply to YOUR research question?”
“Think about your Doc X submission…”

Instagram example or equivalent running case study where relevant
Connect abstract concepts to practical application





Reminder of upcoming deadlines (if within 2 weeks)
How today’s content helps with that assessment
Clear “What to do next” for their project





Key Takeaways (1 slide)

4-6 numbered points summarizing what they learned
Non-incremental so they see the full list

The Bridge (1 slide)

“Today we learned X → Next week we’ll learn Y”
Shows how content connects forward

Questions slide
Optional: Preview of next week’s topic








Primary sections:    #4ECDC4 (teal)
Activities:          #FFE66D (yellow)
Warnings/Challenges: #FF6B6B (coral)
Wrap-up/Synthesis:   #457B9D (slate blue)
Examples/Cases:      #A8DADC (light blue)

:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}

Practical advice, helpful strategies
:::

Things to avoid, mistakes students make
:::

::: {.callout-important icon=false}
## Key Point / Critical

:::

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Two Students Walk Into Office Hours…
text:
Two Students Walk Into Office Hours…


Student A:
“I want to research sustainability in design.”
. . .

What about sustainability?
What about design?
What would you even measure?
Where would you start?

This isn’t a research project. It’s a topic.

Student B:
“I want to understand how material choices in packaging affect Hong Kong consumers’ perception of product sustainability.”
. . .

Specific phenomenon (material choices)
Defined population (HK consumers)
Clear outcome (perception)
You can imagine how to study this

This is a research question.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
The Difference Is Everything



Today’s Core Challenge


You’ve identified a gap. You’ve mapped the landscape. You submitted Doc 0 this morning.
But “there’s a gap” still isn’t a research project.
The question is: Can you turn your gap into something you can actually answer?




That’s what separates students who spin their wheels from students who make progress.

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
text:
Where We’ve Been (Quick Recap)


Week 1-2
Instinct → Validation
“I think there’s a problem here”

Week 3
Landscape mapping
“Here’s what already exists”

Week 4 (Today)
Gap → Question
“Here’s what I’ll actually investigate”

title: DESN2003: Research for Innovation
section: Doc 0: You Just Submitted — Now What?
text:
Doc 0: You Just Submitted — Now What?



Submitted Before Class?


Good. Feedback will come within the week.
Today’s session will help you refine your thinking — so when you get feedback, you’ll know how to act on it.




Common patterns we’ll address today:


Topic ≠ Question — Many abstracts describe an area but don’t ask something specific
Gap ≠ Question — “This hasn’t been studied” isn’t the same as “What happens when…?”
Scope issues — Too broad (“sustainability in design”) or too narrow (trivial)
